evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

slot_statements.defeater_resistance: There is no evidence in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 preliminary history that contradicts or defeats the assertion of communication/coordination breakdown among crew.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of crew resource management failures identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 preliminary history.

defeaters: Evidence showing explicit communication or coordination breakdown among crew in the preliminary history
Direct quotes or reports documenting communication failures or misunderstandings
outcome.reasoning_summary: None of the provided history evidence items (H1-H4) explicitly document or observe a communication or coordination breakdown among the crew; they describe actions and positions but do not indicate breakdown.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings are considered part of environmental or marking features relevant to the deficiency claim.
defeaters: If additional evidence showed the TRP markings were clear and visible or that the pushback was stopped before reaching the TRP, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: H4 directly describes the aircraft moving beyond the TRP ground markings, indicating the presence and observability of an environmental or marking deficiency at the time of the preliminary inspection.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit description of the condition or visibility of the TRP markings; ambiguity whether the markings were deficient or the pushback was improperly controlled.

The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

node.statement: Communication equipment was operational and accessible to the crew

defeaters: If evidence showed the interphone or headset equipment malfunctioned or was inaccessible to some crew members, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 indicates that communication equipment (aircraft’s interphone) was used by the flight crew and headset operator, implying operational and accessible communication equipment. H3 shows the headset operator was physically present and active near the tug, supporting accessibility. However, no direct statement confirms the equipment was fully operational or accessible to all crew members at all times.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit confirmation that all communication equipment was fully operational and accessible to the entire crew; only partial indirect evidence is available.
